title: NERF MP40 barrel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a NERF barrel extension modeled after the WWII German MP40 sub-machine gun. You can read more about it on Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MP_40

There is a "bayonet mount" ring mount that lets you connect it to some NERF blasters. "Twist-lock". Some trimming of the connector may be necessary. Or you may need to add a couple layers of masking tape to get a tight fit, depends on the blaster. DO NOT FORCE CONNECTION or you may break your NERF blaster.

The added length might increase the accuracy of your shots. But it might not.
I would love to get feedback from people.

Designed in OpenSCAD

Printer:

Wanhao 4s

Notes:

On my printer, using Cura to slice, I am able to print this model with out any supports. There are some minor issues with the overhangs that clean up nicely.

YOU probably want to use supports. I like using a raft or a brim with my prints.

There is a "bayonet mount" ring mount that lets you connect it to some NERF blasters. "Twist-lock". Some trimming of the connector may be necessary. author: crocot

title: Delta raised heated bed mount for 2020 aluminium profile

description.text:
The mounts are designed to raised the heated bed from the base for 12mm in order to have a little distance between the stepper motors and the electronics underneath the bed.

My original design uses only M3 screws which is not ideal for mounting on the 2020 aluminum rail. The new design uses M4 screws, so that you can easily slot a M4 square nut into 2020 the aluminum rail in order mount the base. The new design also come with an embedded M3 nut so that the thread for the clip will hardly loses it grip even after a lot of taking off and putting on. The base also uses a single screw so that the angle can be easily adjusted for tighter fit. You probably able tight fit the bed without the clips if you wish to maximize the print area.

3 sets are the minimum, you can use up to 6 sets for even more secure mounting.

Materials for each set

  • M4 x10MM x1
  • M4 square nut x1
  • M3 x 8MM (up to 12mm) x1
  • M3 hex nut x1

How to embed the M3 nuts
The base is designed to be printed as 2 process. you want to manually edit the gcode of your slicer generated to pause at 12mm so that you can embed the M3 nut into the print.

How to install

  1. Slides the M4 nut into the 2020 rail slot.
  2. Screw and align the base to the M4 nut with the M4 screw, do not tighten yet .
  3. Dry fit and adjust the bases according to the bed.
  4. Tighten the M4 screws when you find the correct alignments
  5. Install the clips by using the M3 screws.

Printer:

Delta

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

40%

Stone wall

This is my rural stone wall. It is intended for the 28mm scale and each segment is roughly 10cm (4 inches) long. There are four different segments right now but more are planned. Please comment if you have any suggestions.

Do as much smoothing as you like (acetone with ABS).
Paint it dark gray with acrylic paint.
Drybrush it with a medium gray acrylic paint.
Paint it generously with watered down brown acrylic paint.
Add a second drybrush (lighter) with a light gray.
Do as many steps as you want with drybrush and lighter and lighter colors.
Paint the base the same color as your gaming surface (green).
Or, paint it with PVA glue and sprinkle flock over it.

description.text:
This is my own 12 servo hexapod design. I designed it to be modular and hence easily customizable. Want a 8 legged octopod instead? Print out some extra parts and bolt them on to your hexapod! Its thats easy. No part is greater than 10cm in its longest direction, so this should be easily printed on even the smallest printers. I designed it for the Corona CS-939MG servo, but other servos of similar size may fit. You can see a video of it in action here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jYKSbAZlGfg

Building is fairly straight forward.  you need to print 2 of the "spine" components and 1 spine end cap.  3 of each of the leg bracket 1, leg bracket 2, leg 1, and leg 2 are required.  Lastly you need 6 of the servo brackets.  I printed all parts with 10% infill, 1 perimeter, and 2 solid layers on top and bottom.  
The spine bolts together with 4-40 button head screws, the servo brackets use counter-sunk 2-56 to mount to the circular servo horn, and the legs us button head 2-56 (counter-sunk screws are shown in the photos, but this proved too weak).  Leg brackets bolt to spine with 4-40 screws as well.  
The pictures should make the assembly fairly clear.  The spine has many holes spaced 8mm and 5mm apart, so you can make your own brackets to mount your choice of electronics.  
Any questions, just contact me!

comments.text: The problem with some of the parts printing inside out is that some of the Sketchup parts have faces that are inverted. If you load up an individual part in sketchup and then right click on faces that are light blue, you can then click on "invert face" and it'll be sorted out. My UP! printer was completely messing up the parts until I realised this - you need to invert every light blue face. I'm part way through printing out the complete hexapod and have designed some circuit boards using the ATMEGA328 with current sensors on the power supply to each servo - I'm hoping to be able to detect when the feet are placed onto the ground by the increased current consumption, allowing my software to detect uneven ground and accomodate accordingly

This is a box I created to hold all of the components for a Raspberry Pints and BrewPi setup. They control the digital tap list for beers which include flow meters to monitor how much I have left. The BrewPi is the temperature controller. You can find more information here: http://raspberrypints.com/ and http://www.homebrewtalk.com/showthread.php?t=466106

The front has a mount for a motion sensor and the relay for the BrewPi. The RaspberryPi and Alamode board are mounted on the bottom, along with 2 of these: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B008DS266M/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1 The flow meters plug in to those.

A third screw terminal is on the left in the pictures. That is used to connect the wiring for the rest of the BrewPi. The Arduino Uno is on the opposite side.

The back has a spot for an outlet box needed to control the power to the freezer used as the keggerator. It also has a 12 port wall plate (https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B0032FXOBC/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1). I used Cat5 cables for my flow meters and temperature controllers. I also have passthroughs for USB, HDMI and audio in the plate.

It's a very compact box. I uploaded revision C here and made it a bit bigger than the one I printed. It's really tight! I had to do all the wiring before I screwed everything in place. the other thing to note is that in order to get the card out of the RaspberryPi, you will have to remove the power box to get at it. Also, I had to trim down the cover for the power box because it was too big next to the 12 port wall plate. I was limited based on the size of my printer bed. This was printed on a Wanhoa I3, and if you look at the last picture, you will see it took just over 48 hours to print.

I included the original Sketchup file if you need to make any modification for the parts you have.

print_settings.Notes:: While the top of the ziptie recess fits a ziptie of that size exactly, the bottom recess gets a little squished, so either add 1mm to the ziptie width as tolerance, or just do a little post processing with a file or knife.

description.text:
This design was used to mount a rear bicycle light to the back of my bike. The OEM mount was designed for a seat stem, but I have a pretty hefty rear rack that would occlude the light, and make recharging a PITA. So I designed this.

It is designed so that the light pressure fits/slides vertically into the slot. The mount has recesses for zip ties (of cusomizable width) which attach the mount to the back of the rack (or whatever vertical flat surface you are mounting it to).

The included STL was the one that worked for my LE Rechargeable USB Rear Tail Light (https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B0197X16BC/), but this thing should be customizable to any of the slide-lock cycling couplers.

Put any feature requests in the comments.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Fast/Low is fine

Infill:

15% was fine

Notes:

Print with the slide hole on top/up so that you can print without supports/overhang errors.

While the top of the ziptie recess fits a ziptie of that size exactly, the bottom recess gets a little squished, so either add 1mm to the ziptie width as tolerance, or just do a little post processing with a file or knife.

-Allow the slide slot to be rotated
-Allow printing on a curve, for printing around bars
-Different mounting options: holes, zipties, bolt options for bar clamping
-Documentation inside the .scad file

Put any other requested features in the comments.

title: Upgrades for Ultimaker 2 Clone with RAMPS 1.4 ver1.01

description.text:
Hello!

New upgrades! Easier prints!

Here's the ver1.0 Ultimaker Clone with RAMPS 1.4
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1178406

Here's ver1.02 upgrades - To mount printer on IKEA Trofast kids storage frame
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1829658

1) 3mm filament geared extruder block - Can retrofit original extruder. Note: Marlin firmware (Configuration.h) 'step/mm' for extruder needs to be multiplied with the increased gear ratio. e.g. 16T and 36T would be 2.25:1, hence add *2.25

Or you can use this too:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/belt-geared-um2-feeder-upgrade

Bill of Material:
2 x MF105zz Flanged Ball Bearings (5mmX10mmX4mm)
1 x 5mm diameter, 50mm length, stainless steel dowel pins
1 x 55 teeth, 110mm, 6mm width, GT2 timing belt
1 x 16T, 5mm bore, drive pulley
1 x 36T, 5mm bore, drive pulley
1 X MK8 Extruder Drive Gear, 5mm bore (this seems to perform better than the original Knurled gear)

Filament feeder from:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/alternative-um2-feeder-version-two
Vital Bill of Material:
1 x U604ZZ Bearing U-Groove 4X13X4mm

2) XY slider block is now even easier to print and assemble, just print 2 x symmetrical part.

3) Fan duct reducer, convert 40mm fan to cheaper more widely available 30mm fan

comments.text: How do you wire the fan for power and do you wore in a switch as well?
comments.author: nhillerby

comments.text:
I carefully opened the googles and soldered wires on the battery connector. and then I drilled a 3mm hole in the top for the wires next to the fan.
I assembled the parts in simplify3d and printed them as one part with supports. Came out great!
comments.author: nhillerby

comments.text: Personally, I made up a lead for the battery with a JST for the fan and a jack for the goggles. I have heard of people hard wiring into the goggles but I wanted to be able to use mine without the fan if I wanted to. I have no switch on mine as it simply powers up as soon as I plug my battery in to power the goggles. Another option would be to run it from the balance lead of your battery.
comments.author: nhillerby

comments.text: So the regular connection (could be xt60) from the battery is connected into the goggles with a cord adapter and the balance lead coming out of the battery, I could hard wire the opposite battery lead to the wires coming from the fan and plug that in and take it out whenever I want the fan on? Let me know if that is what you mean and thats how it works. If that is how it does work, how could I wire in a switch because that would be preferred.
comments.author: FPheaVen

comments.text:
I have added a picture of the lead I made up, hopefully that will clear up what I mean. When I want to use the fan I simply plug it in to the JST socket on the lead.
If you want to run it from the balance plug, use the outer two wires for the feed. A switch could then be put in line on the live if you want to.
comments.author: nhillerby

title: Mount for Supernight PSU
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This was primarily designed to be used for Solidoodle printers, but if it will fit, please feel free to try it and give a "Made".
This is by far the easiest and cheapest mounting option for the Supernight I have tried. Once printed, line up the Bottom portion to ensure it is straight, and make three mount holes in the frame with a pencil. Drill out the three holes to accept M3 screws, then slide the PSU into the cradle. Please the Top part over your desired location, but do not cover the venting slits to allow proper cooling of the unit. Mark the two mounting holes as you did with the lower, remove the Supernight, and drill the holes for the Top. After the top is locked in the secured, you can now drop in the PSU. Installation is now complete!

Hardware needed:
5 M3x12mm socket cap screws. M3x16mm should work as well.
5 M3 nuts

description.text:
Designed to be stuck to the wall or cabinet door using double-sided tape or similar. The lip is there to keep the brush in place if mounted to a door (like the bathroom cabinet door).

This is my first full design and was my first learning opportunity for Sketchup.

Creates a 45mm wide x 17mm tall x 47mm deep piece.

Designed around the Escali 100% Pure Badger Shaving Brush (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003WR3QSG/), which has ~24mm diameter x 4mm height indentation just below the head. The tines of this holder grip around this indentation and use the head of the brush to support it.

The design would benefit from pushing the brush a few mm further out from the wall - it's just barely touching the wall for my brush.

Monoprice MP Select Mini 3D Printer

title: Leonardo da Vinci inspired self supporting bridge

description.text:
I designed this bridge puzzle for the Maker Faire Vienna in April. It is inspired by the sketches of Leonardo da Vinci and holds together without any glue, nails or screws thanks to interlocking pieces in the easy version and only due to friction between the parts in the hard version.

For both versions I uploaded a file containing 7 sets of pieces (bridge_xxxx_7x.dxf) which is enough for building a reasonable sized bridge. If you want a bigger one you can cut more pieces using the files for one set (bridge_xxxx_1x.dxf).

You can read a bit more about it on my blog: https://regendrogenbogen.wordpress.com/2016/06/25/da-vinci-bridge/

If you don't have any access to a laser cutter at all, you can buy the kit on Etsy: https://www.etsy.com/shop/DaVinciModelShop

description.text:
Revision 2 is here, the loops for the rear most buttons has been made bigger. Look in my things

You can play with the fill density and wall thickness to get the right amount of flex / strength / and print times if you're in a hurry.

Important, make sure all edges are flat, and the bottom layer has not spread out and is making a raised lip. This will cause problems with the console thinking that the bottom screen is being pressed all the time. You may need to move the brace away from the lower screen b a couple of mm each side... or be a bit zealous with a small file.

Have fun!

author: lucailvec

title: Bowden Cooling Tube for Rostock Max w/ Squirrel Cage Blower

description.text: Squirrel cage blowers can move a LOT of air, which is great for cooling printed parts, but since they're bulky, it's not ideal to have them attached to your 3d printer's end effector. This set of parts lets you mount a squirrel cage blower (one with a round nozzle) in a convenient spot, and then pipe the air to the hotend via 3/8" vinyl tubing. You'll need to print 4 of the clamp ring part, as it takes a pair to make a ring, and use some M3x8 screws to join them. You'll also need some longer M3 screws + nylock nuts to mount the rings to the end effector, or just one long M3x25. I secured the vinyl tubing using some 2 part epoxy, and helped it bond by roughing up the tubing with a little sandpaper first. You can also use black corrugated tubing, which is more flexible, but it tends to make an annoying whistling sound as you crank up the fan speed. The nozzle needs to be printed hollow, and the cap just goes on the end of the tube by the hotend, with a small window cut in the tube right where the gap is in the cap. This lets you direct the airflow exactly where you want it, which is generally in the shape of a cone just at the tip of your hotend nozzle. Please note that the picture is a little out of date, and uses the older mounting rings instead of the new clamp rings. Each new ring is made by screwing together two of the Clamp Ring parts, and flipping one upside down on top of the other, such that the screw holes line up.

comments.text: Tubing the air removes the vibration of the motor for air if placed on any axis.

title: Gimbal Lock for Phantom Pro 3 with PolarPro filters attached

description.text:
I liked essamy's lens cap and gimbal stabilizer for DJI Phantom Pro 3
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1179071
but when I got some PolarPro filters, it no longer fit due to their larger OD. I recreated the cap from scratch using Onshape. An improvement I made is that I put a small lip around the inside of the lens cap so that there will always be a gap between the glass and the plastic cap. This eliminates the need for any sort of soft material to protect the filter.

The source file is here:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/acbf548a74dda4ec434ba9b3/w/fd8127aa7e345aeddd8e99b8/e/0a37b2ad88c490f41644bbeb

I also included a step file.

title: Filament Guide (Clips to 8mm Guide Rod)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a filament guide which is designed so snap onto 8mm diameter guide rods; as shown in the pictures.

There are two separate versions of the filament guide, one is vertical and one is horizontal. Which one you use depends on your printer and especially the position of your spool of filament. I found that having my spool holder where it is, and using the horizontal guide, that my printer was struggling to pull the filament through so make sure you choose the correct one for your printer.

Happy printing! :)

EDIT:

I added a version with a cutout so you can insert the filament into the guide easily. I have not printed this specific version yet so I am not sure if it will print well. I will print it soon.

25%

To ensure that the print will not warp from the bed, I printed at 210 degrees C hotend and 60 degrees C bed; if you do have issues with prints warping off the bed then print with a brim.

description.text:
These are extended combs for the Gillette razor, allowing you to maintain a slightly fuller beard without having to buy a better razor. The original razor set comes with three smaller combs numbered 1, 2, and 3. This set continues with 4, 5, and 6 (updated to include 1, 2, and 3 after requested). 4 and 6 are shown in the fourth photo above. It's very easy to extend these as well for sizes 7 and above. I hold no claim that these are actually to scale and match the original 1, 2, and 3 sizes that come with the razor, so test them first!
Microsoft changed their stl file fixer, so the stl files for 1, 2, and 3 are not fixed (you need to run them through a fixer yourself prior to printing!) Once I can fix them myself I'll upload fixed versions.

XYZ DaVinci 1.0a

I recommend only printing with supports if you have dual extrusion and soluble support material. Otherwise it is too hard to remove the supports from the tiny clasp. When printing without support material you will probably have to do a little cleanup on the clasp and on the finger overhangs.

description.text:
My printer was hating the source design, decided to try my hand at one mine can handle.

https://tinkercad.com/things/6u5DwEen5iU
https://tinkercad.com/things/6cJCLkIRHZi

Power Supply:http://amzn.to/2lh3Zam
Power Supply Jack: http://www.ebay.com/itm/271757190320
Stir Bar: http://amzn.to/2kGlN2f

Picked up some 0.5" neodymium magnets from Michael's. I glued top onto base with ca gel. Then CA glued the magnets into holder, and holder onto fan. It held with just magnet force, but I was afraid it would throw or wobble off over time so I glued it down. For final touch I glued some rubber pads onto the feet. I also ca glued the display into the base, the tabs on the sides are not the most robust mounts out there.

It could be prettier, but black pla is what I had enough of left.

title: Wall mounted double edged (safety) razor holder

description.text:
A companion to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1644738 (shaving/badger brush holder).

This is designed to be mounted to a wall or the inside of a cabinet door using double-sided tape.

I modeled the mount after the Parker 96R - Long Handle safety razor, although any razor with similar dimensions (and a handle with a diameter no wider than 16mm) will probably fit.

This is my second 3D model (the brush holder was the first), and I was just coming to understand the basics of Sketchup, so hopefully it works for other people as well.

This will print with "touching build plate" supports, and I did so (see printer picture). There was some dropping on the bottom and inside of the circle, but overall it's passable, especially when the razor is in the mount.

Finished dimensions are approximately 51mm wide, 19mm tall, and 37mm deep.

Monoprice MP Select Mini 3D Printer

title: Case for uRADMonitor Kit 1 running on a Nokia battery

description.text:
The uRADMonitor is a networked Geiger-Müller counter. More info here: http://www.uradmonitor.com/uradmonitor-kit1-1/ I got mine via the indiegogo campaign.

I have a few extra Nokia batteries (the biggest being a BP-4L), so wanted to use one of those rather than a pair of AA's. It allows a nicely compact case design. But I haven't tested how long it will last on a full charge yet. I'm waiting for the charger I got on ebay first. ;-)

Installing contacts for the battery is really fiddly. Also, the uRADMonitor cannot run from a voltage greater than 3.3V. So, I used a diode, both to cause a voltage drop of around 0.6V (to drop the 3.8V from the battery down to around 3.2-3.3V), and also because the legs of the diode make decent battery contacts for this type of Nokia battery. (I assume you know which way to wire the diode, and how to get correct polarity voltage to the board. You only need the diode on one terminal, and use a cut-off piece of diode leg, or similar-sized solid wire, for the other terminal. Test with a load resistor first, make sure the voltage is safe and has correct polarity, before you solder the contacts to the Geiger counter.) You only need to connect to the + and - terminals of the battery. There is no support for charging the battery, so you just have to remove it and use a desktop charger like the DT-33, or a phone which uses the same battery. My plan is to have the counter running at home from the 5V input most of the time; the battery is just for occasional outings to check radiation levels in other places.

So, I tried to design the case with holes for diode legs to stick through, and end up in the right position to act as battery contacts. The plan was to bend them downwards and shove the ends into the second set of holes, to hold them in place. However the holes ended up a bit small, so I used the soldering iron to heat the diode legs so that they could melt their way through... which resulted in less-precise positioning than I hoped for. But close enough after some adjustment; and then I glued down the ends of the legs to the bottom of the battery compartment, very gingerly, with a small dab of epoxy. I used some epoxy to hold them in place on the inside of the case too, knowing that soldering to them would tend to let them move around again, what with PLA's melting temperature being so low. Then I (very quickly, to avoid melting the plastic too much) soldered a short length of fine stranded wire to the plain-wire contact, soldered that to the negative battery terminal on the board, and finally soldered the other end of the diode (mostly covered in tiny shrink tubing) to the positive battery terminal on the board.

I'm not sure how well those makeshift battery contacts will hold up, but so far so good. It's possible to buy actual Nokia battery contacts on ebay, but they are surface-mount, so actually the thing to do is to design a little PCB which can hold the contacts in place, and in turn is designed to be a part of the 3D-printed case somehow. I didn't get that far yet.

I used #4-40 machine bolts and nuts on the 3 corners that have through-holes on the PCB. The ethernet module is in the way, which is why there is not a hole on the 4th corner, I guess. Oh well, 3 bolts kindof hold the case together anyway. Two of the bolts pass quite close to the Geiger tube, so you'll have to bend the fuseholders (which are used as Geiger-tube-holders) over a little, so the tube sits right up against the side of the LCD. I wrapped that area of the tube with tape just in case there is some voltage on that part of the tube which is undesirable from the LCD's perspective. (And afterwards, check the bolts with your 400V-tolerant voltmeter to make sure they really aren't in contact.) The case is designed with this little mod in mind: there are struts to hold down the tube assuming you have pushed it over into that position.

So all in all, it's quite a fiddly project; but if you got one of these kits, you need some kind of case for it.

I've also added a wall mounting bracket which can attach to the side of my power-over-ethernet wall box http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2085666, and can hold either this type of uRadMonitor kit, or a Model A2, or any other model which gets packaged into the same metal case (lozenge-shaped, 25x75 mm).

A 2 part mount that wraps around the top of the Ultimaker hot end, with recessed slots that let you easily mount things; in particular, the slots are positioned to properly mount 40mm and 50mm fans vertically flush with the edges of the hot end.  
Will not interfere with existing stock or most custom fan mounts.

Print the two parts; you will need to use support because it has flush overhangs. Remove the support and file things nice and smooth so the parts will fit together well. There are two side holes in each part; tap the inner (smaller) ones with a #6 tap or similar metric size.  
To install, remove any existing fan mount, then remove the two long bolts on the left side of the hot end, put two extra nuts on them and spin them most of the way up the bolts, then add either of the parts and reassemble. Gently tighten the new nuts to lock the part in place.  
Repeat the process on the right side, then use two small #6 bolts in the side holes to lock the two parts together.  
Reinstall your fan, and now you have 4 adjustable mount points. You will find that most 40mm fans can be tapped #6, so you don't need long bolts to mount them. Buttonheads are preferred because they are low-profile; so long as they don't project above the slots, you will not have any interference problems with the sliding blocks.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with 4 top/bottom layers at 7 perimeters layers. This many layers is required to achieve strength in the mounting holes. Note: Sailfish 7.8+ was required to allow printing of the mounting holes at any normal speed. You can also try and set max speed change XY down to 1, although it's still not great.

The prototype of a mini ball launcher which will be part of a remote controlled turret for my kids. It is completely 3D printed, except for a cheap, ubiquitous electric motor.

Read http://dlacko.blogspot.com/2016/06/mini-ball-launcher.html for details.

Building instructions:

It is designed to be used with an R140 sized electric motor. You can use a different size, it is an easy change to the openscad source file, but be advised that the RPM really matters. If the motor is too slow, the ball does not fly too far (that is not much fun), if it is too fast, the launcher may be too dangerous (that is not for kids) http://dlacko.blogspot.com/2016/06/mini-ball-launcher.html provides some hint on how to calculate the RPM for a given range.

Use short M3 screws to attach the rotor the the motor shaft and longer M3 ones to fasten the cover to the housing.

The balls should be ~15mm plastic ones.

It is just a prototype, you still need some electronics to control the motor for the proper speed. Use it at your own risk, with a strong motor it might be harmful.

author: LockHar_

description.text:
This is a platform to enable sub-irrigation (self-watering) of a potted plant. Unlike a lot of self-watering setups, this one keeps a dry air gap between the soil and the water reservoir so that the plant won't get "wet feet" as the roots grow down.

It was designed to use a juice jug as the water reservoir, but other containers should work.

I am attempting to use it to revive an avocodo seedling, which lost most of its leaves after not being watered at the local hackerspace...resulting in the goofy looking stick-tree in the picture.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mM

Infill:

10%

The complete setup includes the printed platform, a plant container, a water reservoir, and a piece of wick. I used some cut-up cotton t-shirt strips for the wick.

1) Tie a knot at the top of the wick.
2) Cut a hole in the center of the planter's bottom surface, and push the knot up through the hole (easier if there's no dirt yet, but can still be accomplished with an already planted planter)
3) Cut 2 holes in the reservoir jug: a small one for the wick, a larger one for the watering funnel.
4) place planter on platform and thread the wick through a hole in the platform
5) Carefully place platform and planter over the reservoir so that the wick and funnel go through the holes in the reservoir
6) water through funnel and enjoy.
Created using Meshmixer + Meshlab
customized with 3D Slash!

description.text:
I have a nice three string Loog guitar. The neck is pretty small, so I designed and printed my own wall hook for it. (Also, folks, I am not affiliated with Loog beyond being a happy customer!)

My main goal was to make a wall hook for my guitar that would keep all parts of the guitar from rubbing against the wall, while being strong enough for me to trust it. I didn't want "explosive delamination" to send my guitar to the floor. I used a static load of 3 times the weight of my guitar hanging from the hook to test the strength, and it lasted more than a week without any visible deformation. I included a photo of my test setup.

I took a few CAD classes in college, but all my 3D printing experience before this had been with OpenSCAD. This was my first project using Fusion 360.

I wrote more about this project at my blog, Feels Like Burning.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Notes:

Please, please increase the infill, and do testing before you hang your wonderful guitar using this!

description.text: This is Just a TEST

This is a bed leveling knob for my Voron 3d Printer build.

Check out the Voron subreddit and github:
https://www.reddit.com/r/voroncorexy/
https://github.com/mzbotreprap/VORON

This knob is meant to encase an M3 nyloc nut. It has a 5mm hex slot on the bottom just in case more precision/torque is desired. Make sure you insert the nyloc nuts with the nyloc part facing down.

Instead of leveling my bed from the top (requires drilling my PEI) I decided to level my bed from the bottom by securing my leveling screws to the aluminum bed with serrated flange lock nuts (nylocks won't fare well with the heated bed) and tensioning the bed springs with this knob.

This should work with all iterations of the bed support carriage from the Rev. B to present. I included the F360 file for anyone who wants to tweak the design.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25mm layers

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Brim reccomended, because ABS.
In Cura (lulzbot edition), my 'pause at layer' height was 89. Check before you print.
This took me about 30 minutes to print.

comments.author: gerdescm

comments.text: It depends on your layer height. It should be around 22.5mm but you're going to want to preview your layers in your slicer to see exactly when it would start printing plastic over the nut.

comments.author: mdroman

comments.text: Yup! Most slicers have a 'pause at height' feature, which allows you to pause the print and park the head until user input is given. I used Cura to print this design. The final result is really sturdy, which is optimal for bed leveling.
comments.author: mdroman

description.text:
To see how I created this, watch this video: https://youtu.be/ci7PTxkwbqw

It's time! Mighty No. 9 just released and I thought it would be the perfect time to test my skills making a humanoid type character. So here we have Beck from Mighty No. 9.

I created this model in Fusion 360 using their sculpting tools. I just mostly used cylinders and pulled out sections of it until I had the shape I wanted. Then I used sketches to intersect and scale the details in place.

After printing it I handed it off to my wife for painting. She primed it using an automotive fill primer, then she painted it using acrylic paints and a paint brush.

Filament: Hatchbox White PLA
Layer Height: 0.1mm

Print Time: ~12 hours

description.text: Take a stroll with Grandaddy OLED the watch and light up the night. Use any of your favorite watchbands to easy connect to the OLED Watch case.

Printer:

Flash Forge Creator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.27

Infill:

.10

Designed using 123D SketchUp

Most of my designed was based off of Polylines in combination with extrude function.

Project: Grandaddy OLED Watch Overview & Background:

This project helps gain an understanding of the basics of the Arduino microcontroller,coding,and the modules in order to build a Grandaddy OLED Watch. It works great as a flashlight in a dark place.

Objectives:

Students get hands on experience in the construction of a complex word clock.
Students will learn about basic Arduino coding.
Students learn how to Solder.
*Student learn Schematics.

Audiences:

The grades, ages, or skill levels that would be appropriate for this Project.
4th grade+, Age 10+, Skills in Soldering

Subjects:

This project is based off processing language.

Skills Learned (Standards):

3D Slicing
3D Printing
Motor Skills
Complex Thinking Skills
Teamwork
Problem Solving Skills

Lesson/Activity:

Quick and fun project.

Stuff Needed

Silicon 30AWG wire
coin Battery,coin battery holder

  • I2C 2.42 OLED
    Trinket Pro 5v
    Lipoly Backpack
    500mAH Battery
    DS3231
    *Wire Strippers
    \\\\\\\Optional///////////
    HC-05 (convert into smartwatch)
    bigger batteries.
Arrange the modules in a tetris like formation within the back of the i2c screen cover the back of the i2c Oled in electric tape to prevent any problems with the wire touching. Solder wires to the battery holder contacts Here is the schematics to solder the silicone 30awg wire to the modules. Print out the Oledwatch + 4 small corners. Place the components in the watch glue the insides of the seperate printed 4 corners and place it on the top corners of the OLED case to lock the OLED screen in place On the programming, make sure you download the latest Arduino IDE and simply download the code from here https://db.tt/OLAv2iZR Duration:

1 hour for printing.
1 hours for assembling and programming.

Preparation:

List anything students that should already know about or have done before starting this project, and/or any necessary technology, resources, or materials.

Micro USB cable
Soldering Iron
Lithium Ion Polymer Battery - 3.7v 500mAh https://www.adafruit.com/products/1578
Precision New DS3231 RTC Module Memory Module for Arduino Raspberry Pi
http://www.ebay.com/itm/Precision-New-DS3231-RTC-Module-Memory-Module-for-Arduino-Raspberry-Pi-/400786764495?hash=item5d50c0b2cf:g:m54AAOxy3cJTh-KI
lipolybackpack for pro trinket https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-pro-trinket-lipoly-slash-liion-backpack
Pro trinket https://www.adafruit.com/product/2000

References:

https://www.adafruit.com/product/2000

Rubric & Assessment:

What did the student learn for building this?
Any troubleshooting problems the student encountered?

Handouts & Assets:

https://learn.adafruit.com/introducing-pro-trinket

title: Compact Extruder for Cyclops/Chimera
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
EDIT 12/11/2016: I finally uploaded a change to the design that I have been tinkering with for a while now. It moves the BLTouch mount so that it sits in a recess carved out of the Rail Spacer object, which reduces the amount of filament required. It also makes setting up fans a little easier, and (for me) expanded my functional build volume. I left the old files up in case anybody prefers them (the idlers are the same either way).

This is a compact dual direct-drive extruder I designed to use the E3D Cyclops/Chimera on my RepRap Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3. I decided to design my own extruder because I would have been losing print space on the X-Axis with most of the other designs available. By rotating the motors I can make the design narrower, which allows me to get back that lost print space along the X-Axis.

My design faces the two motors towards each other straddling the chrome rods on the X-Axis & offsetting them so they can be attached using standard M3 screws. I also don't use any bearings on the idlers because I've found that cutting the PTFE tubing in a semicircle around the drive gear works just as well (plus, it doesn't let flexible filament escape as easily). So, all you need to assemble this (minus the Cyclops/Chimera obviously) is a large supply of M3 nuts and bolts. The ones I used are from Hilitchi and are pretty cheap on Amazon if you live in the US.

The RailSpacer model is there to keep me from losing ~12mm of print space due to how my endstops are set up. If your Prusa is able to reach the full print area without the extra boost then go ahead and skip that piece.

Fan mounting points are in front, although I'm still working on a better solution to active layer cooling.There are also two cable tie brackets on the upper right to immobilize any delicate wires and keep them in position

The design was created in Fusion 360, so I also uploaded a STEP file if anyone wants to remix.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Modified Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Designed to print without supports, active cooling fans will help a lot. There are lots of holes on the underside of the main extruder body so running the first layer very slow will save you some headaches, too.

Bill of Materials

BILL OF MATERIALS:

  • 2x Small Cable Ties
  • 2x PTFE Tubing - ~130mm
  • 20x M3 Nut
  • 2x M3 Bolt - 6mm
  • 4x M3 Bolt - 12mm
  • 12x M3 Bolt - 16mm
  • 2x M3 Bolt - 20mm
  • 2x M3 Bolt - 35mm

You could probably get away with using a shorter bolt for the right tensioner, and possibly swap the 4x 16mm bolts on the rail spacer for something longer.

OFFSET NOTES:
On the old design, the BLTouch mount location puts the probe in line with the Cyclops nozzle on the Y-Axis (Y offset 0) and exactly 33mm right (X offset +33) of the nozzle to make bed leveling setup easier.

On the new design, where the BLTouch is tucked into the rail spacer, the offsets are as follows:
Z Offset = 2mm (may vary depending on your hot tighten, but that's what mine is set to at the moment)
Y Offset = 25mm
Cyclops X Offset = 0mm
Chimera X Offset = 9mm from the left nozzle, usually E0. The nozzles should be 18mm apart, so this puts it in the center.

OTHER NOTES:
I designed the bolt sinks based on the bolts I had available, which had somewhat tall caps (~3mm). They should work for other types easily as well, since shorter bolts will just sink in further and it won't have an effect.

Take care to cut your PTFE tubing in the right spot! I recommend inserting it into the heat break and marking it with something. Once it's been cut you can immobilize it by putting an M3 screw.

Credit where due:

This is my original design, but I have to give credit to Amadon for his great work.

Designed with help from some STEP files I inserted into F360 to help me model.
Credit goes to:
MKelly for the Cyclops mockup
MrProto for the extremely detailed NEMA 17 mockup
Inornate for the BLTouch mockups
As well as Folger Tech for the 4-bearing X-Carriage I used (If this is someone's specific design, can you let me know? I'd love to credit them).

description.text:
When printing the rims by xecutor why not print the tires too? Because my VR100 has lost a lot of his tires profile and got more and more problems on carpets and door sills I designed at first a tire with a profile similar to the original one (neato_wheel_tyre_original.stl). To improve the traction on door sills I later made a second version for me (neato_wheel_tyre_climber.stl). It makes a bit more noise on hard ground but because I'm not at home when the robot is cleaning this doesn't matter me. May be that this version is helpful for other users with complicated ground too.

Both models doesn't need support structures.

Recommended print settings:

Material: white or clear TPE or TPU with shore 85A or lower
Extruder temperature: 235°C
Print bed temperature: 80°C
Print speed: 25mm/s

Estimated print time per part: 2h
Material per part: ca. 15g

I printed direct to the glass plate without capton tape because on earlier tries the adhesion of the TPE on the tape was so strong that i lifted the tape from the glass plate when removing the parts.

Edit 2016/06/26: Added the model "neato_wheel_tyre_climber_V2" for better climbing

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm

100%
If necessary, use some drops of super glue to fix the tires on the rims or scale the tires to 99%. I didn't need glue. The tires are sitting tight on the rims with 100% scale.

comments.text: I drew them in MS paint. Once I'm happy with the 2-D black and white drawing I make 2 copies. One is the outline of the head completely shaded in, the other is all the details which I want to be black - hairline, mouth, eyes, etc. Both images are converted to SVG using Online image converter and imported into Tinkercad. The details SVG is turned into a "hole" (negative space) and overlaid on the silhouette so that it engraves the details on the head.

title: BLE Feather Lamp with Inductive Charging Base

description.text:
Based on the BLE Voronoi Feather Lamp from Adafruit [http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1343925]. Modified the original base by creating a ring depression for the inductive charger, changed the sizing of the hole for the switch, removed the curved edge from the top lid so it could print flat, and created a base for the transmitter ring for inductive charging and for the 9V DC jack. Separate power switches on both the Enable ping for the Feather to Ground and on the Inductive charge. Basically wanted the portability of the LiPo without the hassle of having to cable it up for charging.

-Adafruit Feather 32u4 Bluefruit LE: [https://www.adafruit.com/products/2829]
-Inductive Charging Set - 5V @ 500mA max: [https://www.adafruit.com/products/1407]

-NeoPixel Ring - 24 x 5050 RGB LED with Integrated Drivers [https://www.adafruit.com/products/1586]

*I'll just put all the sldprt files so you may mix it easier.

*With rightly printed pla, it will be solid enough to carry a dslr, with more then 20cm of rail.

This is a multi-movement camera slider which can move twice its length.
If you want to attribute, I am working on auto pan right now. We can collaborate.

Designed this to be upgradable wih a controlling rotor via slots on sides.

-Updated side slots for bigger bearing and screw hole.

The missing parts are the belt holders which are easy to design but I don't know which bearing you guys usually use. The bearing hole has 20mm h and 11mm w. Let me know so I can design it for you quickly.

Rail holes are exactly 8mm to make a better fit.If your machine prints exact sizes, you need to have it a little bit smaller.

You will need;

4 x LM8uu or LM8suu bearings for cars
4 x 8mm thick rails
1 x camera holder screw
1 x tripod nut (Check the shape before printing not all are the same)
4x 3-4-5 m3 screws to hold belts
6 x 25mm M4 screw to hold bearings on sides.and for legs
1 x 15mm or longer M4 screw to lock bearing (if desired)
1 x not flexing belt or rope, anything solid enough to connect cars together :)

So let me know whatever you have, we may adapt.

Didn't test myself yet so i cannot tell anything about weight capability. But I guess with 20cm rails it could carry around a 1kg machine without any bending.

Print one and let me know.

Have fun!

description.text: Here are five puzzles made of 5 pieces that can be assembled into a cube. The puzzles are based on a 3x3x3 cube composed of 27 subcubes. This is an extension of thing:1640879 - Four Piece Cube Puzzles. OpenSCAD code is included.

Rafts:

Yes

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 mm

As the number of pieces for these puzzles increases one would expect that a maximum degree of difficulty would occur; with 27 pieces the puzzles become trivial. This set of puzzles has 4 pieces of 5 subcubes and a single piece of 7 subcubes. A possible way to start is to join one of the 5 subcube pieces with the seven subcube piece. Puz_55557_11000
is difficult, puz_55557_11018 is not.

description.text: This is a foot pad for a metal deck chair I bought at walmant. It didn't work out on our deck so I put it out in the yard. The rear legs are mere posts so every time I sit in it, it sinks into the ground. These pads prevent the chair from sinking. The leg diameter is around 18.3mm and I made the pad 18.8mm. With expansion, it makes for a fairly snug fit and my chair no longer sinks when I sit in it.

comments.text: Trying to figure out to get this to print correctly. I tried it standing on end, but it needed a lot of support material and then broke at the base and flange when taking it apart, plus the retention levers on top just snapped off.  Laying it sideways requires a lot of support also and given the dimensions of the flange I'm not sure it won't have the same breakage problem.    I really like this approach and retention better than many others.  Any suggestions on exactly how to get this printed properly in ABS?  Perhaps thicker walls in the design would also help.
comments.author: randysteck

comments.text: Hi Randy,
comments.author: randysteck

comments.text: It appears that I have the same setup as you with the FFCP and S3D.  ABS has not been a problem since I use a glass bed with ABS slurry for adhesion.  Always happy to learn a new technique for printing, but I had several problems when this was printed "on end" as in photo #6.  The biggest was that the spring clips on the side and the flange on the bottom broke off since the layer to layer dimension is the weakest direction.  Was there another orientation you were suggesting?
